ipv6_what_is.title: What is IPv6?
ipv6_what_is.simple_explanation: It's the modern upgrade to the internet's addressing system. The old system (IPv4) ran out of space years ago. IPv6 fixes this by providing a practically infinite number of addresses, better security features built-in, and smoother connections for mobile devices.

compression.title: The Double Colon (::)
compression.simple_explanation: IPv6 addresses are naturally very long (32 numbers!). Because they often contain long strings of zeros, we use a '::' as a shortcut to say 'fill this empty space with zeros'. It keeps things tidy.

prefix.title: The Network Prefix (e.g., /64)
prefix.simple_explanation: This number splits the address into two parts: the 'Neighborhood' (Network) and the 'House' (Interface). A /64 is the standard standard size for a single local network (like your home Wi-Fi).

address_type_global_unicast.title: Global Unicast Address
address_type_global_unicast.simple_explanation: A Public Internet Address. This address is globally unique and can route data anywhere on the internet. If you have this, you are 'live' to the world.

address_type_link_local.title: Link-Local Address (fe80::)
address_type_link_local.simple_explanation: A Local-Only Address. Every IPv6 device creates one of these automatically to talk to neighbors on the same wire or Wi-Fi. It cannot go onto the wider internet.

address_type_loopback.title: Loopback Address (::1)
address_type_loopback.simple_explanation: The 'Self' Address. This is used by the computer to send messages to itself for testing or internal communication.

scale.title: The Infinite Scale
scale.simple_explanation: IPv6 is 128-bit, while IPv4 is 32-bit. This isn't just 4 times bigger; it's exponentially massive. We will effectively never run out of addresses again.

canonical_form.title: Canonical (Short) Form
canonical_form.simple_explanation: This is the 'clean' version of the address. We remove leading zeros and use the '::' shortcut to make it easier to read and type.

expanded_form.title: Expanded (Full) Form
expanded_form.simple_explanation: This shows every single bit of the address explicitly. It's useful for computers and engineers to see exactly what's going on, but it's too long for daily use.

network_range.title: Network Range
network_range.simple_explanation: This defines the boundaries of your specific slice of the internet. It shows the very first and very last address available to you.

total_hosts.title: Total Addresses
total_hosts.simple_explanation: This is the number of unique device addresses available in your network. Even a small home network has more addresses than there are stars in the galaxy.

header_version.title: Version (4 bits)
header_version.simple_explanation: This field always contains the number 6, confirming that this is an IPv6 packet. It's the very first thing a router checks when seeing a packet.

header_traffic_class.title: Traffic Class (8 bits)
header_traffic_class.simple_explanation: This marks how important or time-sensitive the data is. Video calls get priority over file downloads. It helps routers decide what to send first when they're busy.

header_flow_label.title: Flow Label (20 bits)
header_flow_label.simple_explanation: This tags all packets belonging to the same conversation (like a video stream) so routers can keep them together and process them efficiently.

header_payload_length.title: Payload Length (16 bits)
header_payload_length.simple_explanation: This tells routers exactly how much data is being carried after this header. It's the size of the actual content, measured in bytes.

header_next_header.title: Next Header (8 bits)
header_next_header.simple_explanation: This tells the receiver what type of content comes next—is it a TCP segment, UDP datagram, or maybe another extension header? It's a roadmap for parsing.

header_hop_limit.title: Hop Limit (8 bits)
header_hop_limit.simple_explanation: This is a countdown that decreases by 1 at each router. When it hits zero, the packet is discarded. This prevents packets from looping forever if there's a routing mistake.

header_source_address.title: Source Address (128 bits)
header_source_address.simple_explanation: This is the full IPv6 address of the device that sent the packet. It's 128 bits long—the same addresses we calculate and visualize in this tool!

header_destination_address.title: Destination Address (128 bits)
header_destination_address.simple_explanation: This is the full IPv6 address of the intended recipient. Every router along the way reads this to decide where to forward the packet next.

eui64_visualizer.title: EUI-64 Calculation
eui64_visualizer.simple_explanation: This demonstrates how an IPv6 address is automatically created from a device's MAC address. It splits the MAC address, inserts 'ff:fe' in the middle, and flips a specific bit to mark it as unique.
